conclusion: Pressures from A to B: 1.0 × 10⁵ Pa; Pressures from C to D: 0.75 × 10⁵ Pa
Volumes from A to D: 3 L; Volumes from B to C: 4 L
The process A → B → C → D → A is a rectangle on the p-V diagram
A→B: isobaric expansion (p = 1.0 × 10⁵ Pa, V: 3 L → 4 L)
B→C: isochoric cooling (V = 4 L, p: 1.0 × 10⁵ Pa → 0.75 × 10⁵ Pa)
C→D: isobaric compression (p = 0.75 × 10⁵ Pa, V: 4 L → 3 L)
D→A: isochoric heating (V = 3 L, p: 0.75 × 10⁵ Pa → 1.0 × 10⁵ Pa)
Use the ideal-gas law to relate temperatures: T ∝ pV (at constant nR)
T_D = T_A (symmetry of the rectangle) = 300 K
Compute work W for the full cycle: W is the area of the rectangle
W = (p_high – p_low) × ( V_high – V_low ) = (1.0 × 10⁵ Pa – 0.75 × 10⁵ Pa) × (4 L – 3 L) = 25 J
Positive because the cycle is traversed clockwise, so the gas does net positive work on the surroundings
Apply the first law for a complete cycle: Over one closed cycle, the internal-energy change ΔU = 0 (state function)
First-law statement: ΔU = Q – W ⇒ 0 = Q – W ⇒ Q = W
Q = +25 J (net heat absorbed by the gas in one cycle)
